title: Protocol to obtain high-quality single-cell RNA-sequencing data from mouse liver cells using centrifugation
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Step one: Liver perfusion
Timing: 21–25 min
High quality liver perfusion is critical to wash out red blood cells and completely digest the liver so that it is ready for the dissociation into individual cells.
Fill the bubble trap with pre-warmed EGTA Working Buffer before liver perfusion.
Euthanize mouse using isoflurane in an animal holding jar.
Move animal to a flat experimental table and perform laparotomy as soon as the mouse is dead.
Expose Internal Vena Cava (IVC) of the mouse.
Cannulate IVC with 18-gauge catheter.
Note: The site of IVC cannulation is above the renal veins and below the liver.
Stabilize the catheter after cannulation to ensure it does not move throughout the perfusion.
Use absorbable tissues to remove extra fluid around the liver. See Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1].
    Your browser does not support HTML5 video.
  
Methods video S1. IVC cannulation and initiation of EGTA buffer perfusion. Related to major step one, sub-steps 4 and 5
Use all of the 35 mL of EGTA Working Buffer to perfuse liver and wash out RBCs. The total time of EGTA perfusion is 5–8 min depending on the mouse diet.
Note: A well-perfused liver looks pale at the end of perfusion. See Methods video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1].
When the liver starts to look engorged by the EGTA Working Buffer (usually 3–5 s), cut the hepatic vein.
Carefully clamp the IVC above the diaphragm immediately after cutting hepatic vein.
Note: Please make sure the catheter is in place without movement.
After perfusing the EGTA Working Buffer, take the end of the tubing out and directly put it into the 50-mL centrifuge tube containing pre-warmed Pronase Working Buffer within 3 s. Perfuse the liver with the entire 35 mL Pronase Working Buffer.
Note: Total perfusion time is 8–10 min.

Place heat lamp over the liver during all enzyme perfusion steps including Pronase and Collagenase D Working Buffer perfusions.
Note: Make sure the transition among different buffers is smooth and bubble trap remains filled. See Methods video S2[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc2].
After perfusing the Pronase Working Buffer, perfuse liver with the entire 40 mL of Collagenase D Working Buffer. Total perfusion time is 8–10 min.

Note: In the end, the liver should be soft and well-digested. See Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2].

Step two: Dissociation of livers cells
Timing: 25 min
This step is to dissociate the digested liver to release all liver cell types. The homogenized mixture is a combination of all liver cells and debris. The goal is to have few clumps of liver tissue.
Add 5 to 10-mL of preheated Liver Dissociation Buffer into the 60-mm cell culture dish with the liver. Use tweezers to dissociate liver until the mixture becomes largely homogenous.
Note: Total time is 5–8 min. See Methods video S3[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc3].
Transfer homogenized liver mixture to a clear Boston round bottle with black phenolic polycone cap.
Note: Add the remaining 40 to 45-mL of pre-heated Liver Dissociation Buffer together with 600 μL DNase Stock Solution into the glass bottle. See Methods video S4[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc4].
Further dissociate homogenized mixture in glass bottle above using gentle rotation by hand swirling in a 39°C water bath (see video) for 20 min. See Methods video S4[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc4].

Critical: Sub-step 10, see Methods video S3[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc3]. Sub-steps 11 and 12, see Methods video S4[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc4].

Step three: Gradient centrifugation
Timing: 90 min
This step is to wash homogenized liver tissue mixture to remove debris and undigested liver tissue.
Transfer homogenized tissue mixture into a 50-mL centrifuge tube by filtering the mixture through a 70-μm cell strainer.
Centrifuge the mixture at 580 g at 4°C for 10 min.
Remove and discard the top 40 mL without disturbing the bottom pellet. 10 mL of the supernatant and cell pellet will remain in the centrifuge tube.
Add 150 μL DNase Stock Solution to the tissue mixture and using a 10 mL pipette and mix.
Add 40 mL GBSS buffer to the tissue mixture using a 10 mL pipette and mix.
Centrifuge the mixture at 580 g at 4°C for 10 min and repeat steps 15 and 16.
Add 16-mL pre-made Nycondez Buffer to the mixture and use GBSS buffer to bring the total volume to 48 mL. Mix well using a 10 mL pipette.
Aliquot 12 mL into four 15-mL centrifuge tubes.
Carefully add an additional 3-mL GBSS buffer using a 3-mL syringe with a 25-gauge needle to the top of the 12-mL aliquot so that a gradient can form.
Note: Make sure not to disturb the gradient layer. See Methods video S5[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc5].

Centrifuge the 4 centrifuge tubes at 1,380 g at 4°C for 17 min. Acceleration of centrifuge is set at 9 while deceleration of centrifuge is set at 0. The total centrifugation time is ∼37 min.
After centrifugation, the bottom pellet is a mixture of all cell types. See Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3].

Step four: Liver cells harvest before single cell RNA sequencing
Timing: 20 min
This step is to obtain viable hepatocytes with other liver cell types.
Carefully aspirate the supernatant using a 2-mL plastic serological pipette and discard without disrupting the pellet. See Methods video S6[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc6].
Add 1 mL RBC Lysis Buffer (stored at 4°C) to each of the four 15 mL centrifuge tubes above.
Place tubes on ice for 5 min.
Add 13 mL pre-chilled PBS stored at 4°C to each 15-mL tube and mix well using a 10 mL pipette. Centrifuge at 400 g at 4°C for 4 min.
Remove the supernatant and re-suspend pellet in 1 mL pre-chilled PBS stored at 4°C and transfer the mixture to a 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube using 1 mL pipette set at 500 μL.
Centrifuge cell suspension at 100 g for 3 min at 4°C. Discard the supernatant, and wash pellet using 1 mL chilled PBS and repeat centrifugation to harvest hepatocytes.
Alternatives: Centrifuge cell suspension at 400 g for 4 min at 4°C to harvest both hepatocytes and non-parenchymal cells.
Resuspend hepatocytes using 500–1,000 μL chilled PBS at 4°C for cell counting and determination of cellular viability by trypan blue staining.

Figure 4. Microscopic picture of trypan blue staining of liver cells before scRNA-seq
Note: If experiment is successful, the hepatocyte viability should be 70%–90%. See Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4].
The final single cell suspension is used to generate libraries for all liver cells as described in the 10× Genomics Chromium Single Cell 3′ Library and Gel Beads Kit (version 3) manufacturer’s protocol. https://assets.ctfassets.net/an68im79xiti/51xGuiJhVKOeIIceW88gsQ/1db2c9b5c9283d183ff4599fb489a720/CG000183_ChromiumSingleCell3__v3_UG_Rev-A.pdf[href=https://assets.ctfassets.net/an68im79xiti/51xGuiJhVKOeIIceW88gsQ/1db2c9b5c9283d183ff4599fb489a720/CG000183_ChromiumSingleCell3__v3_UG_Rev-A.pdf].
Alternatives: 10× Genomics Chromium Single Cell 3′ Library and Gel Beads Kit (version 3) is no longer available due to product upgrade. The equivalent kit can be used. https://www.10xgenomics.com/support/single-cell-gene-expression/documentation/steps/library-prep/chromium-single-cell-3-reagent-kits-user-guide-v-3-1-chemistry-dual-index[href=https://www.10xgenomics.com/support/single-cell-gene-expression/documentation/steps/library-prep/chromium-single-cell-3-reagent-kits-user-guide-v-3-1-chemistry-dual-index].
